19977+A<><head>EXPLANATIONS AND ABBREVIATIONS.</head>
19977+B<><head>EXPLANATIONS AND ABBREVIATIONS.</head>
19978+A<><head>CITATIONS.</head>
19978+B<><head>CITATIONS.</head>
19979+A<><p>All numbers below 107 refer to the text of this Reader, which is cited by page and
19979+B<><p>All numbers below 107 refer to the text of this Reader, which is cited by page and
19980+A<>line; thus, 79^2^ means page 79, line 2. When still more precise reference is needed, the
19980+B<>line; thus, 79^2^ means page 79, line 2. When still more precise reference is needed, the
19981+A<>first half of a line is designated by ^a^ and the second by ^b^.</p>
19981+B<>first half of a line is designated by ^a^ and the second by ^b^.</p>
19982+A<><p>All numbers above 107 refer to the sections of Whitney's Grammar. Observe,
19982+B<><p>All numbers above 107 refer to the sections of Whitney's Grammar. Observe,
19983+A<>however, that reference is occasionally made to grammar-sections preceding § 107, and
19983+B<>however, that reference is occasionally made to grammar-sections preceding § 107, and
19984+A<>that the word “Whitney” is then prefixed to the number to show that the Grammar is
19984+B<>that the word “Whitney” is then prefixed to the number to show that the Grammar is
19985+A<>meant. The grammar-sections sometimes have subdivisions unmarked by letters or
19985+B<>meant. The grammar-sections sometimes have subdivisions unmarked by letters or
19986+A<>numbers. In referring to these, a small superior number is used, and designates the

23219+A<><head>SELECTIONS XXII.-XXVII.</head>
23219+B<><head>SELECTIONS XXII.-XXVII.</head>
23220+A<><head>EXTRACTS FROM THE KATHA1-SARIT-SA1GARA.</head>
23220+B<><head>EXTRACTS FROM THE KATHA1-SARIT-SA1GARA.</head>
23221+A<><p>§ 45. The work from which the following extracts are taken holds a rather
23221+B<><p>§ 45. The work from which the following extracts are taken holds a rather
23222+A<>exceptional place in Hindu literary history, inasmuch as its date and authorship are
23222+B<>exceptional place in Hindu literary history, inasmuch as its date and authorship are
23223+A<>quite definitely known. According to the author's fancy, it unites in itself all
23223+B<>quite definitely known. According to the author's fancy, it unites in itself all
23224+A<>stories as does the ocean all rivers, and he therefore calls it the ‘Ocean of the
23224+B<>stories as does the ocean all rivers, and he therefore calls it the ‘Ocean of the
23225+A<>Streams of Story’ or Katha1-sarit-sa1gara. Following out the metaphor, he divides
23225+B<>Streams of Story’ or Katha1-sarit-sa1gara. Following out the metaphor, he divides
23226+A<>the work into one hundred and twenty-four chapters, called {@taran5gas@} or ‘billows.’
23226+B<>the work into one hundred and twenty-four chapters, called {@taran5gas@} or ‘billows.’
23227+A<>By another division, independent of the one just mentioned, the work is broken into
23227+B<>By another division, independent of the one just mentioned, the work is broken into
23228+A<>eighteen books, called {@lambakas,@} which Brockhaus, without authority, conjectured
23228+B<>eighteen books, called {@lambakas,@} which Brockhaus, without authority, conjectured
23229+A<>to mean ‘surges.’ The work contains about 22,000 distichs, that is, about one- [Page332-a+ 68]
23229+B<>to mean ‘surges.’ The work contains about 22,000 distichs, that is, about one- [Page332-a+ 68]
23230+A<>quarter as much as the Maha1-bha1rata, and not quite twice as much as the Iliad and
23230+B<>quarter as much as the Maha1-bha1rata, and not quite twice as much as the Iliad and
23231+A<>Odyssey together. An analysis of its contents is given by II. II. Wilson, {%Works,%}
23231+B<>Odyssey together. An analysis of its contents is given by II. II. Wilson, {%Works,%}
